Award.AwardTitle: Designing Axially Chiral Sensors for Enantioselective Recognition of Chiral Compounds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Based on funding from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism Program, Prof. Christian Wolf's group at the Department of Chemistry at Georgetown University will develop molecular probes that differentiate between the enantiomers of chiral amines, alcohols, amino acids and other important classes of compounds. These molecules provide unique opportunities for time-efficient enantioselective sensing of minute samples amounts. This program will explore chiral recognition events and asymmetric induction processes with sensors derived from axially chiral 1,8-diheteroarylnaphthalene N,N'-dioxides, 1,8-bisphenolnaphthalenes, and intrinsically stereodynamic polyarylacetylenes. These three classes of sensors are designed (a) to closely embed interactions with chiral compounds into a highly stereoselective environment (b) to generate a strong chiroptical response to substrate-controlled induction of axial chirality in stereodynamic receptor molecules, and (c) to utilize fluorescence, UV and circular dichroism spectroscopy to quantitatively measure chiral recognition and induction events.

Many biologically active compounds, including pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, flavors, and nutrients, are chiral ("left- or right-handed"), and the majority of today's top-selling drugs are marketed as single enantiomers. The analysis of the enantiomeric composition of chiral chemicals plays an integral role in the drug discovery process and during optimization of asymmetric reactions. Real-time enantioselective analysis with carefully designed sensors that translate a chiral recognition event into a strong UV, fluorescence or circular dichroism signal holds significant promise to effectively complement the advance in automated parallel synthesis and combinatorial methods that can generate large numbers of samples overnight. It is expected that the fundamental and applied aspects of the proposed research will benefit academic and industrial chemists alike and provide high-throughput screening methods that allow rapid enantioselective analysis of large numbers of samples while minimizing waste production and energy consumption.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Generally available high-throughput experimentation technology allows today’s chemists to conduct hundreds of small-scale reactions simultaneously by using automated robotic systems. This advance has substantially accelerated development and discovery processes in many academic and industrial laboratories. With regard to the parallel production of chiral compounds, which are the building blocks of the large majority of pharmaceuticals, however, the analysis of numerous samples is complicate and has remained the major bottleneck. Because chiral compounds exist in the form of nonsuperimposable mirror images, called enantiomers, a comprehensive evaluation of a reaction outcome must include determination of the yield, enantiomeric ratio (er), and absolute configuration (the exact three-dimensional structure) of the product.

With NSF funding, the Wolf laboratory at Georgetown University in Washington DC has developed small-molecule chemosensors that can extend high-throughput screening methodology to asymmetric reaction analysis at low cost while addressing increasingly important sustainability requirements by minimizing waste production and energy consumption. Major steps toward this transformative goal have been made through the development of a variety of probe designs that utilize (chir)optical spectroscopic methods such as ultraviolet (UV), fluorescence and circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy. Specifically, a series of chemosensors that either closely embed interactions with chiral compounds into a highly stereoselective environment or undergo distinct stereomutations due to substrate-controlled induction and amplification of chirality have been designed, prepared and tested. The prospects and operating modes of these molecular sensors are multifaceted and they have been successfully applied in the analysis of a large variety of important chiral target compounds. Time-efficient analysis of the total amount, er and absolute configuration of various classes of chiral compounds is now possible, and this can be accomplished with substantially reduced waste production and energy consumption compared to traditional analytical techniques.

Students with diverse background and from underrepresented groups have participated in this project and received in-depth scientific training with multiple opportunities to present and discuss their research at meetings and national conferences. The fundamental and applied aspects of this chirality chemosensing program have stimulated collaborations with academic and industrial partners. This has significantly enhanced the research and education infrastructure available to undergraduate and graduate researchers. The introduction of new molecular sensors from the Wolf laboratory has provided insights into the chemical reactivity, bimolecular interactions, molecular dynamics and tunable (chir)optical properties of a variety of organic compounds. This work has thus contributed to basic chemical knowledge and extended emerging aspects of stereo- and supramolecular chemistry, e.g. dynamic covalent chemistry, to chemical analysis. The development of high-throughput screening methods for comprehensive analysis of asymmetric reactions (simultaneous determination of yield, er and absolute configuration) is expected to streamline chemical development projects in multiple academic and industrial laboratories.
